Ok, I was looking for this the very first time I saw "physical_network" tag was not considered.

Will SRIOV ports be supported as other PCI devices? If yes, should Neutron request it when a new port is created (maybe this question is for the future development)?

We agreed with Sean that if the physical_network tag is present then nova will use standard VF and PF RCs. So we have multiple options. 
a) neutron can include the standard VF and PF RC in the port resource_request. This is preferred in my eyes. (also the physnet trait could be included at the same time)
b) nova when generates the InstancePCIRequest (as today) from the neutron SRIOV port can insert the VF / PF RC to the request.

I think if we solve the correlation of BW and PF RP (options are at the end of the chapter) then we will see if a) or b) is more viable. E.g. if we got with a scheduler filter then I'm fine to keep the whole thing nova only and go with b).

that via the pci whitelist and the physical_network tag.

it was soon observed that that lead to broken behavior since the nic mac adress did not match the neutron port mac if a non vf was selected.

to adress this vnic-type direct-physical and type-pf were added 

vnic-type=direct-physical explcitly have type-PF in the pci request spec.
when we added it also put a filter in place to remove pools of type-PF if
the request spec does not ask for type-PF,

this filter was a breaking change and broke anyone who had a pci alias with just vendor-id and product id but not a device-type set.


more context:

type-pci device are any device that is not a VF and doese not have the ablity to create a VF in the pci config capablities.

type-PF is any pci device that can create VFs

and type VF is any vf device that does not supprot VDPA

type-vdpa is actully spelled 'vdpa' in the database because the column
limit was 7 and i did not want a db scheme to make it 8 when the type prfix for a device-type column is reduntant.

vdpa devices are any VFs with the vdpa capablity.

they can only be requested if the pci request object has device-type=vdpa and are filtered the same way PFs are when device-type!=vdpa


so puting this all togehter

'type-PF' devices can only be requested if the pci request spec has device-type=type-pf
they can be requested via alia or vnic-type=direct-physical.

'vdpa' devices can only be requested if the pci request spec has device-type=vdpa
and that is only possible via vnic-type=vdpa. it is not supported in the pci alias.

'type-VF' devices can be requested explcitly vai the alias by setting device-type=type-vf or implictly via vnic-type=direct or vnic-type=macvtap

'type-pci' devices can be requested explcitly vai the alias by setting device-type=type-pci or implictly via vnic-type=direct or vnic-type=macvtap.
however when assigned to netorn port the port mac adress will not be updated.


so when we shoudl proably fix this either in a follow up spec when we add neutron sriov port supprot or as part of this one.

vnic-type=direct and vnic-type=macvtap shoudl likely explictly request type-vf

vnic-type=direct-physical shoudl be able to reqest type-pci or type-pf.

today the pci request object cannot accpet a list of device types so this would required an object change and changes to the pci tracker so that it could handel that.

there are other ways to adress such as making the device-type required in the alias. in which if vnic-type direct and macvtap request VF we can remvoe the PF filter. that woudl enable use to remvoe the device-type form the pci request geenreated for vnic-type=direct-physical and it could then consome type-pci or type-PF

thanks for the context. 

Do I understand correctly that for a direct-physical port it is OK to consume a non-netdev PCI device? At least that is what "vnic-type=direct-physical shoudl be able to reqest type-pci or type-pf." suggests to me. Or that is technically prevented by the fact that neutron ports always impose a physical_network request on the PCI device and we don't expect that a non-netdev PCI device is whitelisted with a physical_network tag in the config.

I think it shows a data model issue that a direct-physical port is either consume a type-PF or a type-PCI, BUT, in reality what direct-physical is asking for is a netdev. Some type-PCI devices are netdevs but not PFs, other type-PCI devices are not netdevs. And this breaks our mapping between requested resource class and inventory of a resource class.

* What we are sure about is that an RP is one PCI device. (can be netdev, can be an accelerator, can be a PF)
* We plan not to differentiate between individual VFs under the same parent so we not represent them as child RPs. We just put a VF inventory on the parent PCI device RP (that is in this special case always a PF)
* We are not sure what RC represents a type-PCI that is actually a netdev and expected to be consumed via a direct-physical port.

To resolve the last bullet point I think we need to diverge from the current PCI tracking logic.

Today we have type-PF and type-PCI but they are not distinct sets logically. Hence the consumption issue of a direct-physical port. I think a better grouping would be netdev PCI devices and non-netdev PCI devices. Then we would know that a direct-phyical port always needs a netdev PCI and never a non-netdev PCI. 

So my proposal for the future(I ignoring VDPA in this case but I think the proposal can be naturally extended with that):

* each device from the ``device_list`` that is not a VF represented by an individual RP in placement.
For each non-VF device from the ``device_list``:
* either the ``resource_class`` from the ``device_list`` entry defines the RC for the inventory of this device. 
* or there is no ``resource_class`` but there is a ``phsysical_network`` tag  in the ``device_list`` entry. In this case we assume that the device is a netdev. If it is a netdev but not a VF then we start tracking them as PCI_NETDEV=1 resource inventory. (It can be still a PF or non-PF netdev we don't care, if we need to care in the future we can add a CUSTOM_PCI_PF trait to indicate that it is a special netdev that is a PF).
* pci alias can request any kind of resource class, it can even request PCI_NETDEV or SRIOV_NET_VF
* a neutron direct-physical port will always be mapped to request PCI_NETDEV=1 resource from placement.
* a neutron direct port will request SRIOV_NET_VF=1 resource from placement.

today the semantics of named request groups are as follows

if you set no policy on isolation is giveen be tween named request groups so multiple groups can be satifed form the same RP.

if you set group_policy=isolate only one named request group can be mapped to any one RP.

so the porbem with usin isolate is that if you ask for 2 VF on the same physnet and there is only one phsyical nic and one RP as a result then that request will fail even though there are enough resocues.

on the flip side if you ask for a PF and VF we need to ensure they do not come form the same provider so group_policy=none (the default) will not provide any filtering.

since we dont want  to teach placment about VF and PF resouce classes being sepcial in the placement code it currently has not way to enforce that we cant claim the VF and PF form the same RP.

so to have palcment do that for us in a generic way we need to be abel to specify a list of isolated groups so that placment can do the isolation at the granularity we need or we need a way to say that the two inventories are mutally exclisive in placment data model which might be a better approch in this case but again requires a placment change to model properly.

OK I got convinced to drop the dependent device handling in the new placementy PCI tracing. So we keep it working in the legacy Filter + pci claim + pci tracker case. But when the operator enables the [pci]report_in_placement config to start using this new feature we will start rejecting device_list configs that are enabling both the PF and its children VFs.

For what it's worth, I'm still in favour of (1). As fun[*] as it may be to figure this out, I don't think it's worth doing. IMO this is needless complexity in an already poorly understood piece of the code base. IIRC, it was mainly Mellanox that pushed for this feature back then and their primary motivation was that their PFs and VFs shared a common PCI device ID and they needed some way to distinguish between the two. However, while I understand why someone would want the ability to choose between passing the PF or the VF through to the guest, I don't understand why that decision has to be left until scheduling time rather than being made at initial deployment (via nova.conf configuration). Who is really relying on this functionality?

Also, because I saw it mentioned on IRC, removing support for Schrödinger's CPUs (i.e. CPUs that may be both pinned and unpinned at the same time) caused minimal pushback and ultimately resulted in a much simpler system that was far easier to model. From a Red Hat perspective, this is already in the wild (with OSP 16.x) and I've seen...one bug related to it (which we were comfortable pushing back on). This is a good case study and argument in favour of continuing down the complexity reduction road if you ask me.

so i think there are a three ways to solve this.

1.) we take stephens suggestion and dont allwo you to whitelist a device which is both a PF and VFs. that is a breaking change but means we can model it in placment today.
2.) we add the ablity to have isolation between specific named groups. so rather than nomore then one named group can have resouces form any singel RP it becomes this set of named groups cannot overlap.
3.) we add a way to model mutally exclisive inventories in an RP.
where multally exclisive inventors can have allcoation provided form at most one of the set of inventores and placment would automaticaly reserve the other invetores when an allcoation is made againg any of them.

2 and 3 require placment work but might be reusabel for other problems.
1 is enterily in nova but has upgrade implciations but would result in simpler
pci passthough althoug we would loose the ablity to defer deciding if the PF or VF will be consumed to when we boot a vm.
OK, we can delay deciding between 2 and 3 until we write a placement spec maybe in AA :)

yes that will require pass the allocation candiates to the filter by adding them to the hoststate object as noted belvoe for the numa toplogy filter so that should be pretty simple to do. for this spec i think this is fine. its no worse tehn we have today and placement shoudl significantly window down the set of host the filter has to consider and infact this coudl even allow you to use smaller result set potentially which woudl be nice for larger clouds.

2 and 3 are really the same the real delta is where the code that compute the group isolation live.

in 2 its client side i.e. in nova. in 3 its server side and we just annotate the inventories as being mutually exclisive some how so placemnt can generate the isolated groups internally.

2 is defintly more in line with how placmenet works today. 3 is more work up front but its kind of set and forget. it would always maintian the exclusive state and make any allocation against one inveotry atomicly resever the capastiyt of the others so its harder to break the invairent.

So I think the tri state ``[scheduler]pci_prefilter`` (True,False,None) has the following use case:
1) None (the default): Use the prefilter if the min compute service version is high enough. This is to support the rolling upgrade of an deployment already using PCI passthrough
2) True: Use the prefilter without a compute service version check. This is to support the rolling upgrade case when PCI passthrough is only added to the new computes and the deployer does not want to wait for the rolling upgrade to finish before the prefilter start acting towards the new computes. (I think this is a fairly rare case so we might be able to ignore it)
3) False: Never enable the prefilter. This is to support deployments with hyperv and PCI passthrough as the hyperv virt driver will not have PCI tracking in Placemenet support right now.

If we say we want to ignore #2). Then we can fall back to a single boolean where True means enable if the min service version is high enough.

I'm definitely not an expert but if it's s similar amount of work it seems like a good idea to support both required and forbidden (this is me assuming users like to also specify forbidden traits when allocating PCI?). And as for the syntax, I think to keep consistent with whatever is already being done in placement for required vs forbidden.

flavor extra_spec uses:
  
  trait{group}:{trait_name}=forbidden|required

I don't think we want the tag name being dynamic so we cannot follow this. 

Placement API uses 

  required=trait1,!trait2 

that is recently being evolved into the more complex

  required=in:T3,T4&required=T1,!T2 

syntax. And this gives great flexibility but it needs "required" to be repeatable. That again we cannot really replicate in tags. 

I would prefer <nothing>/! over the +/- syntax if we go there to keep some level of consistency at least with placement.

As the alias is always mapped to a single request group we never have to handle group names in the tags. So we can use the postfix to do repetition.

So lets have a tag named 'traits', with this spec we support <nothing>/! prefix on trait names in the value of the 'trait' tag to express required/forbidden traits. Later on this can be extended to repeat the traits tag with a free text postfix to express more complex things and we can also allow 'in:' prefix:

  traits1=T1,!T2
  traits2=in:T3,T4

So 'trait' will be forward compatible

Generating RequestGroups via a prefilter will not work for us. The prefilter runs in the scheduler service and even if the request_spec is modified by the prefilter to include the new groups, the conductor will not get back the modified request_spec from the scheduler (or the InstancePCIRequest object). Therefore we cannot really communicate the request group -> RP mapping via the request spec or the pci request. The only way to do this is via the Selection object that returned from the scheduler as that contains the mapping for each selected host and alternates. But for this to work we need to create the request groups in the request spec before the scheduler is called as the conductor will try to copy the mapping to the request group in the request spec after select_destination call returned from the scheduler with the Selection object.
Done

We should not do that. A flavor based InstancePCIRequest could ask for more than one device via <alias-name:2> flavor extra_spec. Such flavor extra_spec is translated to a single InstancePCIRequest with count=2. If we translate that to a single named RequestGroup(RC=2) then placement will only return candidates where both PCI resource is fulfilled by the same RP. This is obviously incorrect in a situation when the user asks for two PFs via the alias.

So instead, we have to translate all the InstancePCIRequests (coming from the flavor) into the unnamed (unsuffixed) request group. As that group is can be fulfilled by the whole RP tree.
Done

... buut the unnamed group will not work because there will be no information in the provider mapping returned from placement which InstancePCIRequest is fulfilled by which RP and therefore we cannot drive the PciPassthroughFilter to select the same RP of the request. Basically to fulfill a complex scheduling we have to match request to PCI pool to RP.

The latest solution in the implementation series is to map nstancePCIRequest with count=2 to two RequestGroup(RC=1). And connect generate RequestGroup suffixes based on the request_id and a running index to count 1, 2.
if this is not a prefilter then we should name this something else. [scheduler]pci_in_placement is the current name I working with.
Done

note we might want a nova status check for this ^ but i think we can leave that out of scope this cycle as its not really needed until we actully want to change the default for reporting in placment.

at that point we should have a nova status check for now its not needed since operators that dont opt-in dont need to do anything on upgrade.

This whole sentence talks about 'service token'. Service token is treated as 'Token/Endpoint' auth plugin. Removing just '--os-url' in this sentence is not reasonable. (As you know, 'Token' auth plugin is still valid, but this change does not treat or have any effect on the 'Token' auth plugin.)
